source.title: Section 3. (DAY 0) Pre-determination of the amount of tissue to use for Hi-C

source.body: The pre-determination section quantitates the amount of DNA contained in a cell/tissue pellet prepared in the previous section. Pre-determination should always be performed for tissue samples, but it is optional when the DNA content in a pellet is estimable,. e.g., for cultured cells and nucleated red blood cells.

source.body:
This section includes the following steps.
  1. Cell/tissue permeabilization - Steps 26 - 51
  2. Restriction enzyme digestion - Steps 52 - 54

The number of cells to use for Hi-C is determined based on the amount of DNA.
Use 1×106 cells for an animal with the genome size of 3-3.5 Gb (e.g., human and mouse), or 2×106 cells for an animal with the genome size of 1-1.5 Gb (e.g., chicken and western clawed frog).
For tissue samples, use a pellet that contains 2-10 μg of DNA.
Follow cells/tissue resuspension steps as written, i.e., vortex mix or pipet mix.

source.body: The concentration of the DNA samples in a trio (ctr-1, ctr-2, and Hi-C DNA) should be within two-fold of difference, to accurately observe the size shift by Agilent Bioanalyzer or Agilent TapeStation.

source.description:
Analyze
of the DpnII-digested DNA sample (ctr-2 and Hi-C DNA) using the Agilent Bioanalyzer with the DNA High Sensitivity chip, and
of the DpnII-digested DNA sample (ctr-1) using the Agilent TapeStation with the genomic tape.

source.body: Only ctr-2 and Hi-C DNA of the DpnII digested samples are analyzed using the Agilent Bioanalyzer with the DNA High Sensitivity chip, because ctr-1 (pre-digested DNA), >50 kb in size, exceeds the limit of the DNA size that can be analyzed. Alternatively, the DpnII-digested DNA samples can be analyzed using the Agilent TapeStation with the genomic tape.
For the HindIII-digested DNA samples, analyze of ctr-1, ctr-2, and Hi-C DNA using Agilent TapeStation with the genomic tape.

Only qualified Hi-C DNA showing the expected pattern of size shift, i.e., reduction in ctr-2 and recovery in Hi-C DNA, with no or minimum degree of DNA degradation in ctr-1, ctr-2 and Hi-C DNA, is used for the preparation of the Hi-C library.

In the case of multiplexed sequencing, adaptors should be balanced for their nucleotide composition at each sequence position of the index sequence.
When sequencing a single library, it is better that the library is made using a mixed index adapter (e.g., + ) to balance the nucleotide composition of the index sequence.
We recommend using the UDI (unique dual-indexed) adapter to identify and remove index-hopped reads in the Illumina sequencing platform.

The number of cells to use for Hi-C is determined based on the amount of DNA. Use 1×106 cells for an animal with the genome size of 3-3.5 Gb (e.g., human and mouse), or 2×106 cells for an animal with the genome size of 1-1.5 Gb (e.g., chicken and western clawed frog). Follow cells/tissue resuspension steps as written, i.e., vortex mix or pipet mix.

source.body:
This section consists of the following steps:
  1. End repair - Steps 187 - 204
  2. A-tailing - Steps 205 - 222
  3. Adapter ligation - Steps 223 - 240
  4. Pre-PCR (releasing DNA off the streptavidin beads) - Steps 241 - 255
  5. PCR cycle pre-determination - Steps 256 - 260
  6. Amplification of the library for Hi-C library QC (QC2) - Steps 261 - 276
  7. Library amplification - Steps 277 - 292
Library preparation is performed using the KAPA LTP DNA library kit but in a 1/5 reaction volume of the original protocol and with an additional step for PCR cycle pre-determination.

source.body:
This section includes the following steps
  1. Cell/tissue lysis - Steps 30 - 38
  2. DNA extraction and quantification - Steps 39 - 57

The pre-determination section quantitates the amount of DNA contained in a cell/tissue pellet prepared in the previous section. Pre-determination should always be performed for tissue samples, but it is optional when the DNA content in a pellet is estimable,. e.g., for cultured cells and nucleated red blood cells.
Follow cells/tissue resuspension steps as written, i.e., gently mix or pipet mix.

source.body:
This section includes the following steps.
  1. Cell/tissue permeabilization - Steps 58 - 83
  2. Restriction enzyme digestion - Steps 84 - 86

The number of cells to use for Hi-C is determined based on the amount of DNA.
Use 1×106 cells for an animal with the genome size of 3-3.5 Gb (e.g., human and mouse), or 2×106 cells for an animal with the genome size of 1-1.5 Gb (e.g., chicken and western clawed frog).
For tissue samples, use a pellet that contains 2-10 μg of DNA.
Follow cells/tissue resuspension steps as written, i.e., vortex mix or pipet mix.

source.description:
Quantitate DNA using
of the DNA samples with the Qubit dsDNA High Sensitivity Kit.

The following procedure should be performed as described in the step-case for the dissociated cells.
Start from Section 7. (DAY3) Hi-C DNA QC (QC1), Step 109.
Dissect and collect tissue in a microtube (1.5 or 2.0 ml) and freeze immediately in liquid nitrogen.

source.body: Store the frozen tissue in an ultra-low temperature freezer (e.g., ).

source.description: Pre-cool the Tokken stainless-steel tubes and bullets in liquid nitrogen.
Transfer tissue (up to 4 mm3 in size) into each stainless-steel tube.

source.body:
Break a large tissue into small pieces if necessary.
Do not let the tissue thaw during the powderization process.

source.description: Put a bullet in the stainless-steel tube and close the screw cap.
Assemble the Tokken tube holder with three stainless-steel tubes.

source.body: The tube holder should always be assembled with three stainless-steel tubes to balance the weight.

source.description:
Submerge the tube holder (with tubes) in liquid nitrogen and wait ~
.
Take out the tube holder (with tubes) from liquid nitrogen and immediately place inside the Tokken acryl-grinder, then vigorously shake the grinder for about 100 strokes to powderize the tissue.
Remove the bullet and collect the powderized tissue in a microtube (1.5 or 2.0 ml) pre-cooled in liquid nitrogen.

source.body: Hand warm the lid of the deep-frozen microtube before closing its lid; otherwise the tube may break.

source.body:
This section includes the following steps.
  1. Cell/tissue lysis - Steps 30 - 38
  2. DNA extraction and quantification - Steps 39 - 57

The pre-determination section quantitates the amount of DNA contained in a cell/tissue pellet prepared in the previous section. Pre-determination should always be performed for tissue samples, but it is optional when the DNA content in a pellet is estimable,. e.g., for cultured cells and nucleated red blood cells.
Follow cells/tissue resuspension steps as written, i.e., gently mix or pipet mix.

source.body:
This section includes the following steps.
  1. Cell/tissue permeabilization - Steps 58 - 83
  2. Restriction enzyme digestion - Steps 84 - 86

The number of cells to use for Hi-C is determined based on the amount of DNA.
Use 1×106 cells for an animal with the genome size of 3-3.5 Gb (e.g., human and mouse), or 2×106 cells for an animal with the genome size of 1-1.5 Gb (e.g., chicken and western clawed frog).
For tissue samples, use a pellet that contains 2-10 μg of DNA.
Follow cells/tissue resuspension steps as written, i.e., vortex mix or pipet mix.

description: Hi-C, a derivative of chromosome conformation capture (3C) targeting the whole genome, was originally developed as a means for characterizing chromatin conformation and is recently employed widely in scaffolding nucleotide sequences obtained by de novo genome sequencing. To gain insights into the best practice of Hi-C scaffolding, we performed a multifaceted methodological comparison and optimized various factors during sample preparation, sequencing, and computation. As a result, we have identified some key factors for efficient Hi-C data acquisition, including preparation of tissues, library preparation conditions, and quality controls of prepared samples. By incorporating those optimal conditions revealed by our experience, we release this customized protocol designated the ‘inexpensive and controllable Hi-C (iconHi-C) protocol’.
